19.60.text: Christmas University Challenge. Asking the questions, Jeremy Paxman.

28.32.text: Hello. We've seen 14 teams of distinguished graduates take part

33.20.text: in this Christmas series, and although there were seven winners,

37.68.text: obviously, only the four winners with the highest scores

41.08.text: are returning for the semifinals, which start tonight.

44.52.text: Now, one might think it'd occur to any team that mugging up

47.64.text: on the names of Santa's reindeer would be time well spent

50.84.text: in preparation for a Christmas competition.

53.60.text: Not so, the team from Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford,

55.84.text: who proved themselves hopeless on Dasher, Comet

58.80.text: and Cupid in bonus questions, that also had them wondering

62.40.text: whether there might have been a Roman god called Prancer.

66.68.text: they were impressive on pretty much everything else

69.00.text: from Christmas carols to Christmas cacti

71.12.text: and did themselves quite a few favours

73.12.text: with their speed on the buzzer.

74.76.text: Their team comprises two writers, a news presenter and an actor,

79.52.text: and their first-round score of 195 made them the first team

87.36.text: Hello, my name's Michelle Paver and I graduated in 1983 from LMH

91.84.text: with a degree in biochemistry and I'm now a novelist.

97.00.text: I graduated from LMH in 1986 with a degree in English.

102.20.text: and professor of creative writing at the University of Bath Spa.

105.76.text:
- This is their captain. 
- Hi, I'm Cathy Newman.

108.36.text: I graduated in English in 1995 from LMH,

111.32.text: and I'm now a presenter for Channel 4 News.

115.64.text: I left LMH in 1988 with a degree in English and I'm now an actor

125.20.text: Now, the second team to qualify represent the University of Hull.

128.80.text: They had 205 points at the end of their first round match

132.40.text: against a team from Newcastle University, who were, doubtless,

136.08.text: far more able than their final score of 25 suggests.

139.60.text: They were strong on Delia Smith, Harold Wilson

141.96.text: and various incarnation of Scrooge, and, as it's nearly Christmas,

145.56.text: we'll forgive them for mistaking Marvin Gaye for Nina Simone

149.52.text: and coming adrift on the mathematics of a plum pudding.

152.36.text: Again tonight, they're fielding a writer,

154.52.text: the president of the union Equity, a broadcaster and a children's author.

161.20.text: Hello, my name is Rosie Millard.

163.72.text: I graduated in 1987 from Hull in English and drama.

167.40.text: I'm a journalist and I'm chair of Hull City Of Culture 2017.

174.16.text: I graduated in 1972 in drama and theology.

177.20.text: I'm president of Equity and I'm an actor.

179.64.text:
- And this is their captain. 
- Hello, I'm Dame Jenni Murray.

183.48.text: I graduated from Hull in 1972 in French and drama

188.36.text: and I now present Woman's Hour on BBC Radio 4.

194.72.text: I graduated from Hull University in 1984 with a degree in mathematics

198.96.text: and these days, I write lots of stuff.

205.96.text: OK. Well, you all know the rules. Let's just get on with it.

208.92.text: Fingers on the buzzers, here's your first starter for ten.

214.08.text: which footballer's FA Cup winner's medal sold at auction for £220,000?

219.28.text: He won the medal at the age of 38 when playing for Blackpool.

229.60.text: Here are the first set of bonuses, LMH.

231.60.text: They're on the works of Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

235.04.text: Colonel Aureliano Buendia is facing a firing squad

238.96.text: in the opening sentence of which novel of 1967 by Garcia Marquez?

- One Hundred Years Of Solitude. 
- Correct.

246.92.text: Which 1996 work of nonfiction by Garcia Marquez

250.64.text: reconstructs the high-profile abduction of ten people

257.60.text:
- I don't know. 
- I reviewed it, and I can't remember the title.

262.04.text:
- Erm... I really can't. 
- You really can't? 
- I really can't think.

269.24.text: Can you think how much you've hurt writers by confessing to be a critic

272.56.text: and not being able to remember what it was you were reviewing?

277.84.text: OK, and finally, for five points, Garcia Marquez's 1989 novel,

282.36.text: The General In His Labyrinth, is a fictionalised account

285.60.text: of the last days of which Venezuelan statesman, known as the Liberator?

295.92.text: No, sorry. It's not coming. No. Sorry.

299.12.text:
- No, erm, I know this... 
- Shall we just guess?

301.16.text: The person that founded Venezuela. Um...

310.32.text: It's Simon Bolivar. Ten points for this.

312.60.text: George Arliss became the first British actor to win

315.36.text: an Academy Award when he portrayed which British Prime Minister...?

324.24.text: So you get a set of bonuses, Hull, this time on a prominent woman.

328.04.text: Firstly for five points, the 11th Duke of Devonshire

330.64.text: said of his wife, "She is on the bossy side, of course.

333.96.text: "But I've always liked that in a woman."

336.00.text: She died in September 2014 and was the youngest

338.68.text: and last of which sisters who included Jessica, Nancy and Pamela?

348.96.text: in transforming which stately home in Derbyshire?

356.52.text:
- It was Chatsworth.

358.76.text: And finally, for five points, according to one of her obituaries,

362.04.text: Deborah's dislikes included women who want to join men's clubs,

367.12.text: drivers who slow down to go over cattle grids,

370.52.text: and which bird of the crow family, known binomially as pica pica?

381.76.text:
- We think a jackdaw. 
- No, it's the magpie. 
- Oh.

389.76.text: which early hominid was thought to represent...?

396.60.text: The first maker of stone tools

398.60.text: and was therefore given a binomial meaning "handy man."

410.56.text: No, I think is the answer.

412.24.text: It's homo habilis. Ten points for this.

414.68.text: "The contestants' green room was a cornucopia

420.52.text: Give the dictionary spelling of the word cornucopia.

433.52.text: Right, these bonuses are on temperatures, LMH.

- Asia? 
- Asia? Yeah?

475.72.text: and pressure below a substances triple point on its phase diagram,

479.52.text: which phase transition takes a solid directly into a gas?

486.40.text:

- Sublimation?

563.88.text:

- Samoa? Tahiti or Samoa? 
- Samoa.

569.80.text: And finally, this country, which sees in the New Year at GMT +13.

576.16.text:
- That's New Zealand. 
- New Zealand. 
- Correct.

- and director of the Royal Ballet includes...?
